column2: dizzy & double vision past 45 mins after CT
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Home CALL FROM Other had CT this a.m. in Smithfield and is feeling funny, had to get friend to pick her up because she couldn't drive and hos wouldn't let her leave without a driver, is home now, seeing double, happened when pt went from laying down to sitting on the CT table, hasn't stopped yet and it's been 45 mins, dizziness too, no contrast, no meds this Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , May 19, 2015 10:41 Follow-up Details: Please Follow-up by: Denny Cook RN , May 19, 2015 10:53 Additional Follow-up Details: Go to ER if symptoms persist. Additional Follow-up by: MD, May 19, 2015 4:31 Additional Follow-up Details: She is feeling better now but it really scared her. She said it was very upsetting. I explained that the crystals in her middle ear can sometimes get out of wack and that can make you feel very strange and tired. She said that something like this has happened before in the past but not to this extent. Since she is doing better now she will stay home but if it happens again she will go to ER. Action Taken: Phone Call Follow-up by: Denny Cook RN , May 19, 2015 4:44

Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller: Other Mom states pt had a seizure on 05/14/15. Wanted to make Dr. xxxx-xxxxxxx , May 18, 2015 10:19 RNA Follow-up Details: Called xxxx-xxxxxxx , mom was able to get him to bed, sz lasted 7mins, diastat given. Mom stated have giving the diastat the sz stopped. After sz pt slept through the night. Was lathargic the next day with a HA and vomiting Friday morning. EMS was called and evaluated pt that night, the next day went to PCP who evaluated and wrote new rx for diastat, advised to inform Dr. Zinn. Pt has not been seen in clinic since Currently pt is doing well. No further sz since then. No lingering fatigue, HA, or stomach issues. No new medications, will take Nasonex as needed for allergies, mom states to start ADHD meds later on, but not started yet. Advised mom to schedule ROV with pt since has not been seen in so long. Mom agree. No ROV until July, which will be past 2yr mark for ROV, will need Dr. Zinn, if scheduling IOV there are some still open in June, which is before 2yrs. Unsure how to schedule. Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Home Cell CALL FROM Caller: Other Pt is looking to signed up Cataract surgery and wanted to know if Dr. xxxx-xxxxom has any comments or advice for the pt regarding this procedure. He is concerned about being able to stay still and wans to know if there is a better time to have the procedure done where medications are at peak level or other medications that might help with movement during procedure. Pt would like to be called xxxx-xxxx , comments and Follow-up Details: First, there is no specific contraindications to the surgery. Just make sure the anesthesiologist/surgeon knows what medication you are Second, since most of the uncontrollable, dyskinetic movements occur at the peak of your dose you may want to try to be at the end of dose for the scheduled surgery time. Usually, if they are using any sort of general sedative or anesthetic than that it will reduce the amount of extra movements. I would not anticipate any major Follow-up by: Bradxxxx-xxxx MD, May 27, 2015 12:17 RNA Additional Follow-up Details: Talked w/ pt to inform of BJR's advisement of no specific contraindications to surgery and he doesn't anticipate any major problems. Pt stated surgeon & anesthesiologist is aware of his current

column2: Pt would like to try Propranolol
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Other: CALL FROM Caller: Other I have been trying to contact you for several months now. I have attempted to leave messages through the office number, but have been placed on hold for extended periods. While I enjoy my job and my supervisor is lenient, I cannot take the time to stay on hold for 30-45 minutes at a time. I have still not be able to access the patient portal and it will not let me reset my The Topiramate is not working. I have had some beautiful hallucinations, ranging from glowing forms to numerous chandeliers hanging from the ceiling, but I think that is the effect we were working towards. I have also been very groggy in the morning afterward and have not been able to drive safely. As a result of both, I have stopped the medication. The tremors in my left hand still continue, along with the cramping effect and the locking of the fingers in certain positions. I have not noticed any significant increase or decrease in the change of the tremors. The locking of the hand and fingers varies according to my daily activities. I have noted that the effects on my hands are worse after carrying heavy objects in my left hand/arm or after a day of extensive typing and keyboarding. If I hold an object in a fixed position, my hand tends to lock in that position. Morty has had to assist me a couple of

Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Other: CALL FROM Caller Name: Caller: Other Daughter has some concerns about patient, he seems to be going down hill Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , May 1, 2015 2:49 Follow-up Details: Spoke w/ pt's dtr Yvonne (okay per HIPAA). Yvonne states that pt's mental condition continues to decline gradually after hospitalization (starting early March and lasting for 2 weeks). Pt doesn't realize who his spouse is and mixes up his daughter's identity. He gets angered easily and talks often about going back to Four Oaks (where he was born and raised). Yvonne understands that it will take time for pt to recover after hospitalization, but is worried that he's worsening instead of getting better. Pt's wound is still healing. He sees the wound doctor weekly and has home health twice weekly. They were concerned about infection, but the doctor ran many tests and determined wound was not infected. Dtr denies any additional signs of infection. Pt is now on Aricept 23mg. Action Taken: Provider Notified, Called xxxx-xxxx , May 4, 2015 9:19 Additional Follow-up Details: These kinds of conversations need a visit. Not really much acutely that can be Additional Follow-up by: Virginia Jethro PA-C, May 4, 2015 9:48

Default Paragraph Phone Note OTHER INCOMING Caller Name: Reason for Call: Details: xxx-xxxx-xxxx , on Aricept. Some worsening cognition since March hospitalization for small bowel obstruction. Off of the Humira and Leflunomide for his rheumatoid xxxx-xxxx , patient becamse angry because home health was called xxxx-xxxx , as another daughter is with him. Ms. Daughtry wanted to know if some sort of drug could be called in to calm him down. Described to her some of the problems of starting an antipsychotic on him over the phone, icnluding the blackbox warnings.. He had problems with Haldol during his hospitalization, so it sounds like he got delerious Gave her the option of calling EMS, police if thngs got out of hand, but overall, and emergency room. it sounds like he has calmed down, and is reasonably safe for him to stay at home with the daughter's there. They will keep toorrows appointment. Clinical List

I asked them if the patient would have to redo a sleep study, she stated no. That all we would need to send is an updated Rx for the equipment. She said that she will file it with insurance and if they require a more recent office note, then we will have to schedule him a quick follow up with Susannah. I forwarded this information to Susannah, so she can build a new Rx for CPAP Equipment to be sent to Apria. Follow-up by: Nicole Stone, May 20, 2015 1:38 Additional Follow-up

column2: Son (hippa) calling to discuss recent chgs in mental state **
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Other: CALL FROM Caller Name: 715 310 Caller: Other Son (hippa) calling to discuss pt's care prior to next ROV // States there are some mental changes in pt since last seen, showing sexual aggression towards nursing staff, refusing to walk and aggitation // Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , June 8, 2015 3:29 Call Follow-up Details: Son called back and RN discussed with him what was going on with patient. He says that he's in Wisconsin now but he stays in contact with the caregivers for his father. He says that for the last few weeks, he has been making sexual advances at the caregivers. In particular, there was a 25 y/o female that he is not returning. He will grope them or himself or make verbal sexual innuendos or advances. RN informed him and educated that sometimes this can be advancement of disease progression, especially when frontal lobe, impulse control has deteriorated. He says he's working closely with PCP as well. RN informed him that underlying infection does need to be ruled out first and informed him of most common. He also reported pt's complaints of progressive weakness. PCP is working to get a manual w/c for him. Son wants patient to see WGF only. RN scheduled him for an appt w/ WGF for 6/19 at 9:45a, 9:30 arrival. He v/u and appreciation. He says he's not

Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Other: CALL FROM Caller Name: Caller: Other LOV 5/21/15 ROV 9/18/15 Pt has had a sharp change in behavior. Pt is more irritable, has an increase in anxiety, her mobility has decreased and she is not eating and drinking well. Pt will stand for long periods of time without sitting and will rant and rave about nothing. Pt has had an increase in falls. Pt believes that she is back in the abusive relationship that she had with her 1st husband. Dtr thought pt may have had a UTI due to the changes so she took pt to PCP a few days ago but urine sample came back negative. Dtr also thought that pt had a yeast infection last week, as pt was rubbing herself with the towel vigorously after shower, so pt was treated with a 1 day dose of monistat. Asked if pt has been taking her meds as prescribed dtr states that she just found out that pt has been spitting out her meds so now husband is watching more closely when she takes them. Dtr believes that it may be time to place pt in a facility where they can better take care of her but husband does not want that. Dtr is concerned for patient's safety, especially with the increase in falls. column2: LM: Directions for titration for gabapentin
column3: Default Paragraph Follow-up Details: Pam, could you pls call patient and give him some information for me? He is taking Gabapentin 600 mg po qid. We discussed slowly titrating this up over the next few weeks, but I did not write it down like I normally do. I sent an Rx to his pharmacy for Gabapentin 100 mg po tabs. So, I would like for him to titrate up according to this schedule over the next few Week 1 - 600 mg po tid, 700 mg once in the Week 2 - 600 mg po bid, 700 mg po Week 3 - 600 mg po daily, 700 mg po Week 4 - 700 mg po If he has any SEs, he should give us a call. Default Paragraph Medfusion - Secure Electronic Message Subject: RE: Hello Susan. I have ordered an EEG at xxxx-xxxx , I am not suspicious that any of your symptoms are occult seizure. I ordered because this is the second time you have requested one in the past 6 I believe your dizziness is secondary to disease. However, it can be difficult to rule out the side effect from the medication. When we first switched you to the ER preparation it seemed to help. However, after your last 2 seizures we did increase her dosing your level is in the high normal range. That could contribute to a sense of imbalance, less frequently described as dizziness or vertigo. I will check a level again. If dizziness persists we may not be able to use Lamictal as monotherapy to treat your seizures. You can come in for your Lamictal level at your convenience. You can also wait until you have your EEG to have your Lamictal level drawn that same Dr. (end of message Message queued for Medfusion Member (ID 5036201) on Tuesday, January 06, 2015 at 3:43

Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller: Prescription Other Prescription pt has not taken the meds you prescribed to him (nortpittyline) due to the side effects he read about. Would like to talk to you about your thoughts on the side effects. Please advise Follow-up Details: What are his specific concerns? We discussed common symptoms at his office visit (dry mouth, constipation, drwosiness, sometimes weight gain). These are the most common side effects reported IF people have side effects. I started him on a very low dose. The goal is to make you feel better not worse. If he experiences bothersome side effects then he can stop the medication. Follow-up by: Stacey Carroll ANP, January 16, 2015 11:13 RNA Additional Follow-up Details: RN called and spoke with patient. He was concerned about side effects he had read about on the internet. Discussed with him Stacey Carroll's message above, the common side effects and that he was starting on a very low dose. Informed him that if he does experience bothersome side effects he can stop the medication and contact our office. He verbalized understanding and was appreciative. He will start the medication tonight and contact our office with any problems. Additional Follow-up by: Paige Boyce RN, January 16, 2015 2:16

column2: Numbness has now moved up to her rib cage from her waist
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller Name: Caller: Other Pt calling to inform that her numbness has now moved up to her rib cage (from her waist) on both sides. Cramping has increased in left foot now as well. Please Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx January 2, 2015 11:49 Call Follow-up Details: Pt called and states that the numbness has crept up her rib cage. Please call back to advise @xxxx-xxxx January 5, 2015 12:07 RNA Additional Follow-up Details: Spoke with pt, she says that her symptoms have spread more since she was last in office. At the LOV, her numbness didn't come above her waistline, now they come right under her bra line. She says it's all around, front and back, below her bra line. She says it started to spread last week. It's constant. It worsens after her PT core exercises. It lessens if she's still. Her arms are intermittent, tingling and numbness - like going to sleep. WGF told her to tell him if her symptoms worsened. Her EMG/NCS test is scheduled for 1/9. Action Taken: Provider Notified, Called Additional Follow-up by: Jennifer Taylor RN, January 5, 2015 1:39 RNA Additional Follow-up Details: Will check

Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller Name: Caller: Other husband says pt had a slight seizure on xxxx-xxxx urday. pt has been home resting ever since; he also wants to know if nyquil is compatible with seizure medication. please call to discuss her Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , January 26, 2015 10:17 RNA Follow-up Details: Spoke with Harold, he stated that xxxx-xxxx , was the second seizure that the pt had. It wasn't as bad as the first seizure - in fact it was quite different than the first. It was very brief. The first seizure, she went pale and started shaking, occurred in April 2013. This time, she was completely red, went stiff as a board, and her eyes were all "bugged out". He couldn't really say exactly how long it lasted, just stated that it was short. EMS came out and by the time they got there, she was coming back around, "back to her baseline". They were there for awhile and after much deliberation, they determined that there really wasn't much need to put her through going to the hospital. So he kept her home all weekend to monitor her. No further episodes occurred He also stated that she has been coughing a little in her sleep and her nose has been draining clear fluid. He thinks that she has been coming down with a cold. I informed him that a cold could cause

She reopened a new PA. A verbal one was completed. She is moving it to review and submitting w/ the clinicals that were received. Case # 623003480000. They will try to call first with the decision. Default Paragraph Phone Note CALL FROM Caller: Prescription Medication Prior Rachel called to let me know she has not heard from anyone regarding Plegridy. I called MS Active Source again today and spoke to Tara. She suggested I call UHC to see where the appeals process is, but in the meantime, she was going to have the case manager call Rachel and get the process started for the complimentary dose. I was told the process Case Manager calls patient and submits request to their Pharmacy contacts RNA to verify Pharmacy fills and ships out I have notifed Rachel the case manager will be I spoke to Simon at UHC at 2:08pm and he stated that the appeal was denied on 1/12 and we should be receiving a letter Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , January 14, 2015 2:10

column2: Pt was walking into the kitchen and he fell, leg/foot gave out
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller Name: Caller: Triage Pt was walking into the kitchen and he fell. Pt states that xxxx-xxxx , January 26, 2015 9:58 RNA Follow-up Details: Spoke with Gwen, she said that pt and wife were at home yesterday. Wife was in the kitchen fixing lunch and pt got up from the living room chair to go in and help her. In the kitchen, he ended up collapsing on top of her. Pt has a h/o his foot dragging. He doesn't amb w/ any assistance in the house. Dtr came over and took pt's BP. She stated he looked pale. BP was 70/40. She got him up and waited, it spiked to 170/. Around lunch time, it finally normalized, & so did pt's color. Pt has been on cymbalta 30mg qd almost 2wk now. Dtr states that's been the only recent change. She reports that pt tried HH PT about 2-3m ago. He doesn't have any interest in pursuing PT again but stated that pt c/o foot dragging and numbness that bothers him constantly. Last night he took his BP when he had a severe headache and it was in the 200s/109. He took his last demerol and went to sleep and woke up with no headache at all. He called his cardiologist yesterday and they wanted to know if this was the maximum dose the patient could be or if he could up. Could the medication possibly be causing this. I explained that this medication is used to treat HTN. The only new medication he has started is B12. He does have morphine that he has for a herniated disc but that does not help his back pain. He states when he does not have a headache he BP is usually in the 130s/80-90s. He also said that WGF said he was going to check into the "Fentanyl Pop." I call Gordon in the RNA pharmacy. column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller Name: Caller: Other Patient was recently seen by her Psychiatrist Dr. xxxx-xxxxxxx who suggested that xxxx-xxxxxxx , but she is now experiencing upper shoulder and back pain and was informed Lyrica may help. Her PCP stated she should go back on Klonopin, but she is requesting the Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxxxxx , January 5, 2015 2:35 Follow-up Details: Please review and advise. Follow-up by: Hollie Saltis RN, January 7, 2015 10:31 Additional Follow-up Details: I would recommend PT and Tylenol or NSAID's for the neck pain. Off-label use of Lyrica for this purpose is not well supported by medical evidence. Clonazepam is contraindicated in a patient with an addiction history who is in recovery. She should obtain a PT referral and NSAID through her Additional Follow-up by: MD, January 7, 2015 11:38 Additional Follow-up Details: RN attempted to call and inform pt of the above, but her cell phone's voicemail was full and her home number had no voicemail. column2: Phone Note- Acute low back pain
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell Phonexxxx-xxxxr CALL FROM Other Galen called. Has had 3 days of acute low back pain. Hard to sit on a low sofa. Violin playing doesnt seem to make it worse. Can't run. Hard to extend the low back or bend over because of pain. Has tried Motrin. Left leg goes numb when supine in bed. Pain worse with Mckenzie lumbar extension Seal Maneuver. No weakness. No known accident or Was advised to Try Ibuprofen 600 mg po tid, and if this fails, will try a Medrol Dosepak. Was advised to lighten his Violin Backpack load (currently around 30 pounds).

Default Paragraph Phone Note CALL FROM Caller Name: Caller: Call For: Reason for Call: Details: They need to discuss patients Namenda. Has the patient tried or failed Aricept? Please call them back to discuss at xxxx-xxxx , January 15, 2015 10:53 RNA Follow-up Details: I called CVS caremark back and spoke with Erica. I used the reference number but she couldn't pull anything up by that number. I informed her of the pt's status. That a PA request came in on the 8th for BID dosing. I called coventry who was the requesting vendor and spoke w/ Wendy who informed me that >27 y/o do not require PA for the Namenda 28mg XR but DO require it for the BID dosing. The XR was subsequently prescribed. Now we are getting pushback from CVS Caremark - silverscript. They are saying that it add'l info is requested. After further review, she transferred me to a different dept to complete the PA. I was transferred to 2 different people. Finally spoke with Terry in the PA dept. Terry stated that pt received the Rx of the 10mg on 1/12. The request for add'l info was for a teiring issue. He says to disregard the request. I called April and informed her that the XR was sent in and to take out the BID dosing Rx from their system so when pt refills next, it'll be the XR strength. She v/u. Action

Default Paragraph Phone Note CALL FROM Caller: Other States started on CPAP last Mon or Tues with no problems. Woke up this past Sun with an am headache, especially painful when she bent over ("like a sinus headache"). She again woke up yesterday with an am headache, worse than the day before. She took some Tylenol, with little relief. Today states she again woke up with a headache which now radiates down the "entire back of my neck" and "my head feels like it's going to pop off my body". It is throbbing. She states she has no nasal congestion or cold-like symptoms. No fever. Wants to know if CPAP could be causing headache? She referenced a prior dx of meninginitis. Please advise ........ Follow-up Details: stop wearing CPAP until the headache goes Then retry it, but be sure the EPR is set to a 1 or Additional Follow-up Details: Spoke with patient. States after taking the Tylenol her headache is tremendously better this afternoon. She repeated herself several times that she feels much better this afternoon. Info from Dr. xxxx-xxxxs relayed. Pt will try sleeping this evening without CPAP to see if she awakens with am headache. I have called and spoken with Summer at FMS in Smithfield to have them call pt to discuss how to set EPR at 1 or 2. Pt knows to expect call. Pt voiced understanding. Will call back with report, knows to call if headaches redevelop once restarting

Default Paragraph Follow-up Details: Pt called to state she did not use CPAP last night and woke up this am headache free. States she spoke with Dan from FMS and her machine EPR is set at 1. Pt voiced understanding. Follow-up by: Wendy Upchurch, January 21, 2015 11:58 Clinical List

What xxxx-xxxx , January 22, 2015 1:24 Follow-up Details: LMOR that the study should help us evaluate for brachial plexopathy. If this is confirmed by the test then she probably should not receive the flu shot in the future. If this is negative, then we will may do studies to look at the neck. But since she stated that the issues that she was having happened after the flu shot then we should go ahead and do the NCS. PN that most people find the test irratating and only a few people find it intolerable. Brachial plexopathy is pain, decreased movement, or decreased sensation in the arm and due to a nerve problem and again to determine what is going on she should have the NCS test and to keep that Action Taken: Phone Call Follow-up by: Linda Clark RN, January 26, 2015 1:48

Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Home CALL FROM Caller: Other Pt states "her ice pick HA's have increased to metal to metal and doesnt know what xxxx-xxxx , January 22, 2015 10:37 RNA Follow-up Details: Pt's HAs have increased in frequency about a week and half ago. They now occur daily. They were more tolerable, and now she's unable to function normally bc of the pain. She cannot drive. Pt describes the pain as more severe as ice pick pains, it feels like "a knife on a knife." Pain is more constant that before, about 10 times daily lasting for 45 seconds to a minute. Pt has been taking Topamax as prescribed. Pt states Fioricet is ineffective. She's took one Fioricet yesterday, and another the day before. Pt does think these are the worse HAs she's ever had, she thinks they're worse than the migraines. Please advise. Action Taken: Called xxxx-xxxx , January 22, 2015 11:23 Additional Follow-up Details: Let's try Indomethacin which is the medication most often used to prevent ice pick headaches. I never gave in the past b/c she was having them so infrequent. Can always go to the ER if not helping or Stacy D said she could try a nerve block on her if she wants to try more aggressive management if the Indocin

column2: Phone Note- generalized seizure following a period of confusion
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Other: OTHER INCOMING Caller Name: Reason for Call: Details: call from the patient's mother- Margot. Pt had decreased lamictal to 25 mg daily yesterday and today as instructed. She started behaving oddly this evening, seeming to be out of it, wanderign and touching the walls. Mother describes this as "absence seizure". Then patient had a typical grand mal seizure followed by post ictal period (10-15 minutes), Pt is waking up now (15 minutes). She has been on Keppra 300 mg po bid, in addition to the Lamictal which was being tapered. Last month was on Lamictal 50 bid. Mother is unaware of any other medications or recreational drugs. Instructed mother to give the pt 50 mg of Lamictal tonight when she is more awake, and 50 mg at lunchtime tomorrow. Will bring this to Dr. xxxx-xxxxs attention in the AM to see if he wishes to maintain the low dose of Lamictal (and clarify the Clinical List

He needs to talk with provider regarding situation and see about another rx. Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , January 23, 2015 10:22 RNA Follow-up Details: RN called and s/w pt regarding above. Patient states that he thought that Maxalt was to take everyday. RN advised pt that Maxalt is a Migraine rescue medication and that he is only suppose to take one at the onset of HA/Migraine, may repeat x 1, but no more thank 2 in a 24 hour period. Caller understood and states that he has recently follow up with Dr. xxxx-xxxxger regarding this. Pt has f/u appt with SMF on 2/23/15 @xxxx-xxxxCaller understood and was appreciative of call. Action Taken: Called Caller verbalized understanding of Follow-up by: Lisa Jones RN, January 30, 2015 9:55

column2: Possible Rx Plegridy inj site reaction
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller: Triage Medication side Rx Plegridy- possible injection site reaction- pt states "there is a red mark on leg where injected, it does not itch, does not burn, does not bother her at all but wants to make sure nothing is wrong." Please advise. Pt is also in research study and wanted Tippi to be aware of Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , January 16, 2015 2:39 Medfusion - Secure Electronic Message Subject: Injection Ms. I received your message regarding your injection site. This can be a normal reaction to subcutaneous injections. With Subcutaneous injections you do have more risk of having an injection site reaction. The redness should subside over time. You can use an ice pack to see if this will help as well. Make sure that you are cleaning the site well and rotating your injection sites. If further syptoms come up please let me know. Thank you. I will also make sure that Tippi is aware of this. Thank Have a great Lisa Jones, (end of message Route responses to Me Notify when Failure Notice 4 Message queued

She said she didn't see a doctor until she was discharged. She was told her MRI showed age-related changes as compared to an MRI from 10 years ago. Her bloodwork showed an elevated WBC.. The doctor told her that her bloodwork was fine on the 2nd blood draw but pt. said they never drew blood again. She said that doctor told her that she was taking too much medication and that the cymbalta had caused her seizures and to decrease it from 90mg. to 60mg. Pt. asked if she had contacted RNA to speak with KMC or HS and that doctor said she did but "they had never heard of you." The patient told that doctor to d/c her from the hospital and she would not change her medication without speaking with KMC or HS. I told her we will get the records from WMC-Cary and have Holly review them and I will call her back on Follow-up by: Denny Cook RN , January 23, 2015 3:34

column2: FYI-patient will continue artane, provides meaningful benefit
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller: Other pt would like a cb she states she has some questions regarding her new medicine. she did xxxx-xxxx , January 21, 2015 4:11 RNA Follow-up Details: RN called and spoke with patient. Patient has started having daily headaches over the past couple of weeks along with joint pain. "her wrists are very sore to move, even when she is just lying in bed." She is currently taking artane 1/2 tab po BID. She has stayed at BID due to the side effects dry mouth and constipation. She recently started nortriptyline 5 days ago previously prescribed by Dr. xxxx-xxxxo see if that will help with her headaches. She wants to know if the joint pain or headaches can be coming from the artane as well. Patient has upcoming appt 2/5/15. Please advise. Follow-up by: Paige Boyce RN, January 22, 2015 9:05 Additional Follow-up Details: Dry mouth and constipation are common side effects. Headache is a possible side effect but I am not aware of joint pain being caused by artane. is it providing any meaningful benefit? if not i would drop to 1/2 pill po qday x3days then stop to see if it is the cause of the headache or joint Additional Follow-up by: Bxxxx-xxxx MD, January 22, 2015 9:19

Please call back to advise @xxxx-xxxx January 21, 2015 2:09 RNA Follow-up Details: Pt was in on 1/13. She was given aptiom samples (2 weeks of 400mg and 2 wk of 800mg) and then Rx of 800mg Rx to continue after that. She says that she started 400mg qd samples of aptiom on the 14th. about 2 days ago she noticed very small, bright red, broken blood vessels on her feet. So many that it almost looks like a rash. She also has noticed excessively dry and flakey skin that is almost slothing off. She says that it's on the lower part of her legs. She has been putting cream on it but it hasn't been helping. Default Paragraph Follow-up Details: Patient was in office on 1/22 after visit with Stacy Deese, NP. Was seen by Bernard Campo for troubleshooting of CPAP issues. Notes of this encounter per BC, as "This pt just showed up in the lobby after an appt with dr xxxx-xxxxth some questions about his CPAP. He was having leaking issues and complained that his was freezing cold at night so I can only use it for an I brought him back to room 5 and tested his machine to make sure the humidifier was still heating (it is) and then had him put his mask on. He was on a medium, which leaked, so I switched him to a large pillow and advised him on how to adjust the tension on the head gear (airfit P10). He was placing both straps behind the crown of his head, which in and of itself was causing some leaking. I reset the humidifier on his S9 to 6.0 (was at 4.0), brought the tube temp up to 80*(was at 67*, he stated he had been playing with the temp Gina told me trying to find a solution) and suggested he place the machine below head level so any condensation that might form will roll back to the machine instead of his nose. (currently has the machine slightly above head level in When he left I told him to give us a call if he has any further Follow-up by: Gina Mauldin PA, January 27, 2015 4:43 Clinical List

Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller: Other pt would like a cb about his next steps with his medication. pls Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , January 13, 2015 3:41 Follow-up Details: I sent you a flag on 1/8/15 to relay my message to the patient. Please do so, as it has now been 5 days since that message was sent and the patient has been waiting to hear Follow-up by: Gina Mauldin PA, January 14, 2015 8:47 RNA Additional Follow-up Details: Per Gina's Please let patient know that I spoke with Dr. xxxx-xxxxs and our current recommendation would be to do a PSG (overnight sleep study without CPAP) followed by MSLT (daytime nap study), stopping Nuvigil 3-5 days prior to the test, but not needing to stop any other medications. The only REM suppressant he is on would be Latuda, which would be a very weak REM suppressant, if any, so his medications should not alter the test results. If he agrees with this, I can put the order in for the test, at which point our office will then call him to schedule this. He would also be scheduled for a 2 week follow up with me after the test to review results. Also let him know that Dr. xxxx-xxxxs noted that often insurance will allow psychiatrists to prescribe Nuvigil to augment treatment for depression, so the results of these

Default Paragraph Medfusion - Secure Electronic Message Subject: RE: Seizure Mr. It is not clear to me that treating you once nightly with gabapentin will maximize your seizure control. Looking back at Dr. xxxx-xxxxxxx , you may of had some partial complex seizures during wakefulness. Gabapentin, almost certainly at higher doses, at night only, may prevent nocturnal seizures but even that dosing is somewhat unorthodox. You may however be able to "kill 2 birds with one stone" with gabapentin for both seizure control and insomnia. If that is her desire then you should increase her dose of gabapentin, my recommendation, to at least 600 mg every at bedtime. Otherwise, given your history, I would treat you with twice daily dosing of gabapentin at a minimum or more likely, switch to a different Dr. (end of message Message queued for Medfusion Member (ID xxxx-xxxxxxx , January 19, 2015 at 9:46

Default Paragraph Clinical List Medfusion - Secure Electronic Message Subject: Re: RE: Seizure Purely for seizure control, I would switch you to generic lamotrigine ER. If you're insomnia is responding reasonably well to gabapentin and that xxxx-xxxx , then 8 months seizure freedom is nothing to laugh at. In that scenario increasing the dose of gabapentin at bedtime and adding a lower dose during the day could be considered. If seizures are your primary worry insomnia much less of a worry, then lamotrigine ER is your better long-term Dr. (end of message Message queued for Medfusion Member (ID xxxx-xxxx , January 21, 2015 at 2:23

She took 5-20mg tabs yesterday. Today, pt reports HA is still there but more controlled w/ Percocet. Her BP is down. She takes Percocet one tab (can take up to two tabs) q4hrs. column2: Pulsating sensation in head, tinnitus. Recently started Depakote
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note CALL FROM Caller: Other Spoke w/ pt's spouse Kathy (okay per HIPAA). Pt started Depakote on the evening of 6/3. On 6/4 (approx 12hrs after medication was started) pt began to c/o tinnitus bilaterally. This has improved slightly since it started. Now, pt c/o a pulsating sensation on the R side of his head (not around his temples). Pt states it feels like he can feel his heartbeat in his head and that "it's pulsating so hard, I think you can see in in the mirror." The pulsating sensation comes and goes. Pt denies any additional abnormal sxs. He is taking Depakote 250mg once daily as prescribed. No additional med changes. Please advise. Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , June 5, 2015 11:17 Follow-up Details: I would stop the Depakote for a couple of days and then retry it and see if the symptoms recur. This might be a transient problem with Depakote and the question is whether the patient can work through the sensation of pulsating and see if it goes away on its Follow-up by: xxxx-xxxx MD, June 5, 2015 12:30 Additional Follow-up Details: Pt wife Action Taken: Phone Call Additional Follow-up by: Jennifer Ellis RN , June 5, 2015 1:05

Pt stated he is feeling ok now since laying w/ feet propped on 3 pillows but back hurts w/ movement. Informed sp ok to give Tylenol if needed since he has not had any today but to hold on giving another morphine dose. She verbalized understanding. column2: pt would like a cb about her migraine
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller: Other pt would like a cb about her migraine she said its not as bad as it was but she would rather speak to someone than go through the Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , January 6, 2015 12:27 Call Follow-up Details: Pt called xxxx-xxxx , January 6, 2015 4:05 RNA Additional Follow-up Details: Spoke with pt, she says that she is have a horrible time with her migraine. She doesn't understand why WGF would Rx her a med that she already has. I reviewed over her med list, I informed her that the lidocaine and the ketamine NS were not the same medications and she had not been Rx'd them before. She says that she feels like she needs something really strong to knock out her migraine. As previously stated in her AAS message she has tried numerous measures to knock out her migraine w/o success. She has tried steroid taper previously but it took 2 rounds (6d each) after the DHE tx (hospital) to really do it. She is willing to try it again. Rx built for her to do a 9d steroid taper w/ ambien. She also is requesting Rx for hydrocodone. She only has 2 pills left. Rx built. She will get the ketamine filled if this isn't successful. She says that she's tried

column2: Lyrica concern- increased leg swelling and blisters
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Home CALL FROM Caller: Other pt called and is having problems with Lyrica and is breaking out with blisters on her body and swelling.. please advise pt. Follow-up Details: Spoke with pt, states that ever since she increased Lyrica 50mg to 3 pills at night, she has been having increased leg swelling. She states this week she has developed blisters to her legs, stomach, and feet. She saw her PCP yesterday who advised her to check with PKY re: possibly adjusting her Lyrica dosage. Pt states 2 days ago she decreased the Lyrica to 1 pill at night, so she is currently taking Lyrica 50mg 1 po tid. She states this has reduced some of the swelling. She c/o continued foot pain, burning, and restless legs, though the Fentanyl patch is helping some with the pain. Pt states she has been on Gabapentin in the past which has helped. She is taking Valium at night to help with the restless legs. Please advise and send back to Pam Follow-up by: Lisa Rowley RN, January 28, 2015 1:16 Additional Follow-up Details: d/c lyrica and present for follow up discuss alternatives. ok to work in with Additional Follow-up Details: Notified pt of PKY response. Verbalizes understanding. She states she is going to contact Dr. xxxx-xxxxd's office first before scheduling appt with our office and will call

column2: rev'd free meds here for pt
column3: Default Paragraph Follow-up Details: placed call to pt's home. a female answered the call. I asked to speak w/ pt. she stated that pt can not speak. I asked who she is and the pt was then placed on the phone. I told him that we recvd a shipment of his keppra and I was trying to see what was going on since I was not aware of this. he grunted. she then got back on the phone and again I asked who she was. she stated that it was Theresa- she is on hipaa. told her that I have recvd his keppra. That I will have them at the front and she will need to sign the recpt when she picks this up. she became upset stating that I did not have the right to open the box. advised that box is addressed to SAG. she still felt that I should not have opened the box. Advised that she needs to sign receipt. she insisted that I sign this form and that I seal the box up- advised that it is the policy that she signs the form. She was advised that there were 24 bottles in the box and that I will have it a the pharmacy for her to p/u. She insisted that I sign it since I opened the box and that she has never had to deal with this at any other facility. She wanted me to sign the packing slip that there is 24 bottles recvd. advised that I can not do so as the packing slip notes #2, not #12x2 (packaged in a bundle of 12). Advised that rx and slip is at front pharmacy. pharmacist recvd Action Taken: Phone Call Follow-up by: Linda Clark RN, January 29, 2015 11:08 Clinical List

column2: hallucinations/ change to seroquel Rx called
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Home Cell CALL FROM Caller Name: Caller: Triage Pt's daughter called and stats that she's tallking to people who aren't there and she's not sleeping and she'd like to speak with the RN. Please call back to advise @xxxx-xxxx January 16, 2015 9:01 RNA Follow-up Details: spoke with daughter and pt is "up all night", having conversations with people that are not there , seeing people who have been dead for "years" , wandering, increased imbalance, eating a paper towel. Daughter states decline has been more drastic over past 1-2 weeks. Pt was seen by pcp on tuesday (neg urine for UTI and CT scan showed no change). PCP ordered physical therapy for balance, but explained to family that this may help "very little". Nurse will discuss hallucinations and not sleeping with provider and call daughter back with plan of care. Pt does take risperadol 1 mg 1/2 tab in am and 1 tab at night. Also on zoloft 50mg and celexa 20mg in Action Taken: Called other family Follow-up by: Valerie Mead RN, January 16, 2015 9:48 Additional Follow-up Details: I would stop the Risperdal and change to Seroquel 25mg. 1/2 a tab in the morning (IF NEEDED) full tab at night.

I told him since I again had to leave a VM that I was going to assume that the reason for the noncontrol release generic lamotrigine was due to cost or insurance restraints as there is no documentation in his chart that he needed anything other than what was sent in to Harris Teeter on 12/16/14. I also told him we do have 24-48 hours to respond to a refill request and as KMC is rounding at the hospital this week I am covering other doctors, thus the delay in getting back to him today rather than yesterday. My message on his cell phone was a calm and very nice explaination of time frame for prescription refills. I have called in the Lamotrigine 100mg. to Harris Teeter to Jennifer and cancelled the rx. for the Lamictal Follow-up by: Denny Cook RN ,

column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Home CALL FROM Caller: Prescription Other Prescription Pt states that xxxx-xxxx , it is not causing side effects, it just is not Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , January 22, 2015 9:11 RNA Follow-up Details: Returned call to patient and she stated that she has tried the Relpax and Cambia twice and neither times have been effective. She had 1 headache on Monday and since her appointment has had 4 additional headaches. She feels that the pain is getting more severe every day and hopes that her headache are not starting to become like they used to be (24/7). She does admit that she she has had a very busy week. She woke up with a headache this morning and tried the Replax and Cambia which did not work. She would like to know if there are any other recommendations? Please Action Taken: Phone Call Completed, Called Caller verbalized understanding of Follow-up by: Brittany Lloyd RN, January 22, 2015 9:22 RNA Additional Follow-up Details: Since she has had so many headaches, I would suggest a short steroid taper to calm things down and then we could try something like ZOmig Nasal spray. This is a a triptan so she would have to wait until tomorrow to try it.

Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Other: xxx 455 CALL FROM Caller: Other seems to be having issues with swallowing; may be related to botox, please Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , January 22, 2015 9:50 RNA Follow-up Details: RN called xxxx-xxxx , (ok per HIPPA) regarding patient's swallowing issue. Last botox injection was 10/20/14. Per husband, patient began having sore throat xxxx-xxxx , she was given antibiotics due to swollen tonsils. Her swallowing issue has gotten worse, she has been in and out of the ER several times. She has had a previous barium swallow study and an upper endoscopy with stretching which have not given a reason why she is having issues swallowing. She is going to be seen by SLP today for another swallow study, and yesterday the speech therapist told them she thought it was a physical problem with the swallowing. Patient has done research online at Mayo Clinic, and saw where issues swallowing and weakness can come from botox, (the website says to report these symptoms days to weeks after injection). Husband wants to know if these issues could be coming from the botox injection, he doesn't have any other idea of where this is coming from. He has already been told the symptoms started to long after the injection, but he wanted input from BJR. Please advise.

column2: Please cosign-Mom is concerned that pt dosage is too high
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller Name: Caller: Other Mom is concerned that xxxx-xxxx , mom would like a c/b. Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , January 20, 2015 2:00 RNA Follow-up Details: Spoke with mom at length about pt's fatigue for the past week. Mom sts nothing has changed about his meds except that he's not taking his multivitamin qday as he should. Mom asked if his Keppra could have "settled in his body after all this time" and be causing his fatigue. Pt has been on the same dose since 2012. I assured her that the fatigue should not be from his daily dose of Keppra. I asked if pt sleeps regular hours and if he has his cell phone in his room. Discussed habits of teenagers of keeping phone in bed on vibrate and texting at late hours of the night. Mom said she would look into this. I can try again a moment later and have no When the problem is most apparent, it also affects yawning: a yawn just kind peters out, without the characteristic deep I have a distinct, uncomfortable tight feeling at my diaphragm. Not pain, and really only uncomfortable because it doesn't feel Spicy food, caffeine, sitting, and tight pants seem to set it off most commonly, but my GI doc doesn't think it's GI. Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller: Other Patient needs an appt sooner than April as she is experiencing Memory problems. Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , February 24, 2015 8:31 Call Follow-up Details: I spoke with pt and she stated that she is having a tremedous amt of wt loss. She says that she is not able to concentrate. She looked at the list of the side effects online and out of 24, she has 20 of them. She says that memory is the biggest problem that she has. She also has depression and SI. She also c/o not being able to sleep. She reports that she is "sleeping some". She is waking 2-3x/night. She is paranoid about everything. I asked if she had a plan to carry out her suicide and she denied any plans. There was some availability on Friday to work patient in. Patient reported that even though per last phone note, she was suppose to be weaning off the trokendi 200mg, she has not. She was still on the 200mg dosage. I spoke with ATP. He said that she could be worked in today d/t his openings in schedule. I called pt back and worked her in for 2:30 w/ 2:15p check in. Pt v/u and Action Taken: Phone Call Completed, Appt Scheduled Caller verbalized understanding of Follow-up by: Jennifer Taylor RN, February 25, 2015 11:03

column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Other: CALL FROM Caller Name: Caller: Appointments Had to cxl Botox for 17th // Needs workin for approx 1/24 // Pls RC // Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , February 16, 2015 10:00 RNA Follow-up Details: I spoke with pt in regards to r/s her botox appt. I spoke with both husband and then pt. They reported that pt had suffered a GI bleed and had been admitted to the ICU about 3d w/ blood transfusions and recently d/c on Monday. It was d/t the stress r/t taking care of her mother-in-law and her advance alzheimer's disease. She is getting quite aggressive with her and the stress is a lot for her. On top of that they think that the NSAIDs (aleve) and steroids could have resulted in the GI bleed. She doesn't remember much but last Wed she was apparently vomiting blood and had called her husband who found her on the kitchen found and called EMS. She was taken to the hospital and resuscitated and given transfusions. The GI ulcer was stopped. She was d/c on Mon 2/16. She is r/s for her botox appt for 2/24 at 8:30a. She will call if she cannot make it. WGF made aware of pt Action Taken: Phone Call Completed, Provider Notified, Called other family Caller verbalized understanding of Follow-up by: Jennifer Taylor RN, February 18, 2015

column2: FYI: ROV due to concern with botox SE and head pains
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller Name: Caller: Call For: Triage Suicidal thoughts or Patient son stated that the patient needs to be seen and she is talking about suicidal threats. They need an appt and patient would like it with Dr xxxx-xxxxxx , February 20, 2015 2:16 Follow-up Details: Pt's son states that the pt has had new B throbbing head pains along with a noticeable mouth droop on the L side. Evidently this has been an issue for the past 3-4 weeks. Pt's son had previously talked to the pt about going to her PCP or the ED, but pt wants to be seen by neurology. Evidently last night pt informed son while on the phone that the head pains were severe and that she "did not want to live this way anymore" and hung up the phone. When asked directly about her suicidality risk, pt's son said that she was safe and would not commit suicide, but just wants the pains to stop. He said that she is safe and is with her daughters at home. Pt's son is concerned with possible side effects of botox. RN stated that if mouth droop is on the same side as the botox injections it could be related to it, but recent issues with increased agitation is not a related to botox. column2: TRIAGE: Pt started a fight at school, pt left a mark on student
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Callerxxxx-xxxx , Behavioral Changes - Pt started a fight today. Pt having worstening headaches. Mom requesting an emergency work Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , February 12, 2015 2:49 Follow-up Details: mom says HA 's started this weekend.Mom says school work and homework has dropped. Pt refuses to do work at school or home. Yesterday he was home bc of sore throat and stomachache. Today he went back to school and was behind a student and pulled on their hoodie and the zipper scratched the student. Mom is not sure if they fought or not, but he was put in ISS for 3 days. Mom says he has gotten out of control over the past few weeks. mom is requesting a 504 plan that the school sent mom and says it can be filled out to request more services through the school system. She will fax the form to xxx-788-8986. Mom says you saw at LOV how his behavior has changed and he has gotten worse. Mom has not contacted anyone for behavior therapy. column2: questions about droxidopa, concerns for BP.

Pt is currently taking 100mg tab droxidopa 2 tabs in am , 1 at noon, and 1 at early evening. Explained that pt's BP is high, but not unusual for her, and she has very labile BP normally. Pt does tolerate BP and is able to do ADL's and "bike" on her stationary bike while taking medication. Nurse advised to continue the routine of medication as discussed at office visit 2 tabs, 1 tab and 1 tab. Continue to monitor BP. Son does state that BP becomes low again by the time her noon time dose is due for droxidopa. column2: 3 szs today, hit head 2 wks ago, stopped Keppra 11/14
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note CALL FROM Caller: Other Call transferred from call center. Mom sts pt has had 3 szs this am. LOV 7/2014, no showed appt in Nov 2014. Phone note from 11/10/14 sts pt was put on Keppra. Mom sts pt took it for a week or two, but school staff told them pt was overly sleepy so they stopped giving her the Keppra. Since then. mom sts pt has been having szs approx q 2-3 weeks. Sts they are 45-60 seconds long, "whole body shaking", "eyes are huge, sometimes rolled back in her head", sometimes wets herself, drools "a ton", then either falls asleep or c/o HA and cries until she vomits, then goes to sleep. She has had a few with sz, but most are without fevers. I asked why she hadn't called our office about stopping the medicine or about the szs q2-3 wks. Mom 1st stated pcp told them if having szs q2-3 wks was her normal then not to worry about it. Later mom sts that you told her the Keppra was the only option for pt and that you weren't sure why she was having szs. I told her that there were med options that would have been discussed if we had known, and that they need to check with us in the future. Mom sts dad's car broke down and she's been without a car but now she has one. Mom then sts that 2 weeks ago pt had a sz outside and fell back, hitting her head on the road really hard. Sts she had "a huge knot" on her head. Sts pcp told them it was ok as long as the knot was on the outside. Now mom is concerned because pt

column2: TRIAGE: Migraine, wants to start preventative
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller: Triage Migraines with high pain Pt having a migraine. Would like to take a preventative. Says she has been having migraines every Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , February 4, 2015 10:31 RNA Follow-up Details: I spoke with pt, she says that she delivered her baby on 1/22. She has been pumping. It is yet to be determined on how long she will be pumping for. She has been using the norco prn but only about 1/2 tab a time about 3x per wk. She says that since delivery her HAs have been daily all day every day. She says that her HAs have been tension type. "gripping down and making her nauseous". She has been trying to stay away from the norco b/c she doesn't know what effect it will have on the baby. I informed her that it could be given to the baby through the breast milk. She wanted to know if she could go on to the NTP or if that would be dangerous d/t her pumping. She also wanted to know if she could use any NSAIDs. She will undergo gallbladder surgery in a couple weeks (2-3). Pls Action Taken: Provider Notified, Called Caller verbalized understanding of Follow-up by: Jennifer Taylor RN, February 4, 2015 1:53 RNA Additional Follow-up Details:

Pt states that she has had 2 severe migraines since her ROV in February that have caused L sided numbness and tingling. Pt is taking Propranolol and Topirimate as directed. Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller: Other Pt called and states that she started taking Paxil a couple of weeks ago and she states that she thinks that it was causing the extreme tremors. So she cut back on the medication and the tremors have stopped and so has the muscle cramping but she's now having withdrawal symptoms from the fact that she's cut down on the Paxil. She's been having weird sensations in her head, zapping,throbbing, hot and cold sensations. Please call back to advise @xxxx-xxxx March 26, 2015 10:32 Follow-up Details: pt stated she stopped paxil 20mg 11 days ago. pt was on paxil x2 m. s/s at LOV and the tremors were discussed at that time. pt was prescribed rx for her hot flashes by GYN. pt stated that the tremors have stopped but now she is having weird sensations in her head of zapping,throbbing as well as hot and cold sensations. pt stated that this started right after she stopped to paxil. pls Follow-up by: Linda Clark RN, March 26, 2015 11:03 Additional Follow-up Details: she may have come off the paxil too fast - some people have a withdrawal type syndrome with comingoff. We can do the 10 mg pills and taper more slowly with 10 mg po qday x 2 weeks then q od x 2 week then off. Additional Follow-up by: xxxx-xxxx MD, March 26,

column2: MIgraine of 7/10 with no relief from medications. DHE order.
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Cxxxx-xxxx patient back Cell Cxxxx-xxxx FROM Cxxxx-xxxx er: Triage Migraines with high pain Pt is still having the migraine from the previous phone note on 5/15. column2: Decreased prednisone by PCP, please advise
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Home CALL FROM Caller: Triage Medication side Patient and spouse called in stating that she is having terrible side effects from the prednisone. She says that her eyes are blurry and she can't see anything. She is extremely weak. Her BG is 500. She would like to come off of the prednisone. She is taking 3 in the morning and 3 in the afternoon. She didn't know the dosage size as there are 2 Rx's in the chart one for 20mg tabs for 3 po qAM and on for 10mg 3 tab qAM and 3 tabs po qafternoon. She stated she was taking 60mg per day. RN informed her that would speak with RM and get back with Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxxxxx , June 18, 2015 10:22 RNA Follow-up Details: Reviewed above complaints with RN. Patient is to follow with PCP closely for DM control- we had discussed need for insulin sliding scale. Please have patient see PCP or ER today. If she would like to come off the prednisone please let me know and we can plan weaning of steroids. We will need glucose management even as we wean steroids. Follow-up by: Rhonda Maloney NP , June 18, 2015 10:34 RNA Additional Follow-up Details: RN called patient and informed her of the above. RN informed her that prednisone was helping her inflammatory myositis and it was to stop the progressive muscle weakness and this was the only treatment. At first, she was not wanting to do the prednisone but RN explained the situation further re: neurological risk and stopping prednisone. She still wants to wean off the prednisone. RN explained per RM that the SEs that she is experiencing is a result of her elevated glucose and needs to be addresses ASAP, either by PCP today or going to ER if she cannot get into PCP. RN stressed that she needs to be seen today to get SS insulin. She v/u and will contact PCP to get it addressed. If not addressed it will continue to increase and create other problems. RN also explained that she cannot just stop the prednisone. She will let us know if she needs anything further. Action Taken: Phone Call Completed, Provider Notified, Called Caller verbalized understanding of Additional Follow-up by: xxxx-xxxxxxx , June 18, 2015 11:06 RNA Additional Follow-up Details: Plan of weaning off steroids: May decrease by 10mg every one to 2 Current: 60mg po 60mg in am 50mg in pm x 1 to 2 weeks 50mg in am 50mg in pm x 1 to 2 50mg in am 40mg in pm x 1 to 2 weeks 40mg in am and 40mg in pm 1 to 2 weeks will then need to see make sue 60mg is current dose/Dr. xxxx-xxxxxxx , June 18, 2015 11:54 RNA Additional Follow-up Details: LMOVMTCB to Additional Follow-up by: xxxx-xxxxxxx , June 26, 2015 9:44 Additional Follow-up Details: Pt states that she is currently taking 20mg po BID and have been for 2-3 weeks. Dr. Rao reduced the prednisone dose several weeks ago. Pt states that she has had a slight improvement, but wants to stop prednisone completely. Pt also states that she is not using Ambien and has used Tylenol PM and Melatonin QHS. She states that this is working for her and she does not want to change to Ambien. Follow-up by: Hollie Saltis RN , June 26, 2015 4:04 Additional Follow-up Details: that is fine if she does not need the ambien. Additional Follow-up by: xxxx-xxxx MD, June 28, 2015 8:52 Additional Follow-up Details: She can drop dose to 15mg bid. ake 1 week then 12.5 mg qd. column2: Increased amount of migraines. Steroid rx.

Please call back to advise @xxxx-xxxx January 20, 2015 8:34 RNA Follow-up Details: Pt is currently taking Topamax 50mg in and 100mg at HS. This dose increase was started on 12/15. It seemed to help at first. She only had two migraines that were easily remedied by Maxalt. However, she's had a migraine for the past four days straight and feels that she's back into her "chronic headache." RN asked if pt had taken Maxalt for her current migraine. Pt has not because she felt it was different kind of headache. RN instructed pt to take Maxalt and then to take Maxalt a second time 2hrs after if her pain had not resolved. Pt will call back this afternoon w/ a progress report. column2: New onset R neck pain, requesting Rx
column3: Default Paragraph Phone Note Call patient back Cell CALL FROM Caller: Other Pt states that he awoke 2 days ago with very persistent R neck pain. Pt denies injury or trauma. Pt states that he had has tried OTC pain relievers with no relief. Pt also states that he tried a muscle relaxer left over from his prior surgery which gave him no relief (pt did not know the name). Pt is wondering if DAK could prescribe a medication for pain relief. Please review and advise. Thank you. Call Taken by: xxxx-xxxx , January 29, 2015 8:57 Follow-up Details: I would suggest combining a clonazepam with an over-the-counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agent. If this is not effective, he may need to see his surgeon about his neck Follow-up by: MD, January 29, 2015 9:31 Additional Follow-up Details: RN reviewed the above with pt. He states that he needs a new Rx for Clonazepam and that he had been informed by his cardiologist that he is not allowed to take NSAIDS like Ibuprofen due to his a-fib. Please review and advise. Rx pending. Additional Follow-up by: xxxx-xxxx , January 29, 2015 11:09 Additional Follow-up Details: Short term use of an NSAID should not increase the risk of bleeding too much, he should check with his cardiologist about how much and how long he can use the NSAID's for
